abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            unsatisfactory, and sustainability is unlikely, while the
            institutional development impact is modest. Lessons are
            derived from design, and implementation of the project. The
            importance of ensuring firm commitments from all sources of
            funding prior to signing, or effectiveness, is paramount for
            a successful project completion; in this case, donor funds
            were not secured, which led to a significant percentage of
            the project not being implemented. Similarly, the Road Fund
            was created, but the Government did not establish
            institutional mechanisms for its operation: had collection
            procedures been established, the Fund would have been able
            to fully finance road maintenance. Suggestions indicate the
            need to clearly define the necessary procedures prior to
            credit negotiations, or effectiveness, and that Government
            commitments back the acceptance of such procedures.
            Moreover, given that procurement is a central issue in the
            supervision of a project, the Bank team should remain close
            to the client, and conduct at least one procurement audit
            following the first year of execution, particularly in the
            case of a newly created implementing agency, who may deviate
            from agreed procurement guidelines. Finally, a general
            recommendation stipulates the need for project restructuring
            in post-conflict cases such as this one, with already two
            project suspensions, followed by a war. By using an
            emergency loan, restructuring could have focused on
            emergency maintenance, rather than policy reforms, placing
            the country in a position to seek follow-on sector funding,
            and resume policy dialogues.
